review.title: Asymmetric Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems
review.abstract: Distributed Constraint Optimization (DCOP) is a powerful framework for representing and solving distributed combinatorial problems, where the variables of the problem are owned by different agents. Many multi-agent problems include constraints that produce different gains (or costs) for the participating agents. Asymmetric gains of constrained agents cannot be naturally represented by the standard DCOP model. The present paper proposes a general framework for Asymmetric DCOPs (ADCOPs). In ADCOPs different agents may have different valuations for constraints that they are involved in. The new framework bridges the gap between multi-agent problems which tend to have asymmetric structure and the standard symmetric DCOP model. The benefits of the proposed model over previous attempts to generalize the DCOP model are discussed and evaluated. Innovative algorithms that apply to the special properties of the proposed ADCOP model are presented in detail. These include complete algorithms that have a substantial advantage in terms of runtime and network load over existing algorithms (for standard DCOPs) which use alternative representations. Moreover, standard incomplete algorithms (i.e., local search algorithms) are inapplicable to the existing DCOP representations of asymmetric constraints and when they are applied to the new ADCOP framework they often fail to converge to a local optimum and yield poor results. The local search algorithms proposed in the present paper converge to high quality solutions. The experimental evidence that is presented reveals that the proposed local search algorithms for ADCOPs achieve high quality solutions while preserving a high level of privacy.

metadata.title: Asymmetric Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems

sections.text: This paper proposes a general framework for asymmetric DCOPs (ADCOPs). In ADCOPs, different actors may have different assessments of the constraints they are involved in. The new framework bridges the gap between multi-agent problems, which tend to have an asymmetrical structure, and the standard symmetrical DCOP model. The advantages of the proposed model over previous attempts to generalize the DCOP model are discussed and evaluated. Furthermore, innovative algorithms that are applicable to the specific characteristics of the proposed ADCOP model are presented in detail, including complete algorithms that have a significant advantage in terms of runtime and network load over existing algorithms (for standard DCOPs) that use alternative representations. In addition, incomplete standard algorithms (i.e. local search algorithms) are not applicable to existing DCOP representations of asymmetrical constraints, and if they are not frequently applied to new COP outcomes.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: "The universe is asymmetric and I am convinced that life as we know it is a direct result of the asymmetry of the universe or its indirect consequences." - Louis Pasteurc © 2013 AI Access Foundation. All rights reserved; multi-agent systems (MAS) often include a combinatorial problem distributed among actors. Examples of multi-agent combinatorial problems are the Meetings Scheduling problem (Modi & Veloso, 2004; Gershman, Grubshtein, Meisels, Rokach, Zivan, 2008), sensor networks (Zhang, Xing, Wang & Wittenburg, 2005; Zivan, Glinton, Sycara, 2009) and Vehicle Routing (Le.

sections.heading: 2. Asymmetric Distributed Constraint Optimization
sections.text: First, the standard DCOP model is presented, followed by its proposed generalization, which covers asymmetric constraints. Next, some alternatives to the presentation of asymmetric constraints by the standard DCOP model are described.

sections.heading: 2.1 Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems (DCOPs)
sections.text: A DCOP is a tuple < A, X, D, R >. A is a finite set of agents A1, A2,..., An. X is a finite set of variables X1, X2,..., Xm. Each variable is held by a single agent (an agent may contain more than one variable). D is a set of domains D1, D2,..., Dm. Each domain Di contains a finite set of values that can be associated with the variable Xi. R is a set of relations (constraints). Each constraint C, R defines a non-negative price for any value combination of a set of variables and is of the form: C: Di1 × Di2 ×.... × Dik → R + (1) A binary constraint refers to exactly two variables and is of the form Cij: Di × Dj → R +. A binary DCOP is a DCOP in which all constraints are assigned to a task A, including a partial value.

sections.heading: 2.2 Asymmetric DCOPs (ADCOPs)
sections.text: That is, domain values are mapped to a tuple of costs, one for each restricted agent. Formally, an ADCOP is defined by the following tuple < A, X, D, R >, with A, X, and D defined in exactly the same way as in DCOPs. Any restriction to anasymmetric DCOP defines a set of non-negative costs for any possible value combination of a set of variables and takes the following form: C: Di1 × Dik → R k + (2) This definition of an asymmetric constraint is natural for general MAS problems, and requires little manipulation in the formulation of variables.

sections.heading: 2.3 Alternatives for Representing Asymmetric Constraints
sections.text: The extension of the Distributed Constraint Reasoning (DCR) paradigm (Meisels, 2007) to asymmetric payouts is of great interest when dealing with real-world issues. Typical issues often have to take into account the individual condition of each actor (remaining battery life, user preferences, etc.), which rarely matches. Previous work has discussed several alternatives to displaying asymmetric constraints by DCOPs.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 Disclosure of Constraint Payoffs
sections.text: The easiest way to solve MAS problems with asymmetrical payments by DCOPs is to disclose compensation, i.e. the aggregate value of all actors acting jointly, but disclosure of compensation discloses private information (preferences) (Greenstadt, Pearce, & Tambe, 2006; Maheswaran, Pearce, Varakantham, Bowring, & Tambe, 2005; Yokoo, K.Suzuki, & Hirayama, 2002) and in many cases must be avoided.

sections.heading: 2.3.2 Use of Unary Constraints
sections.text: One possible technique for displaying preferences and influencing different payouts is by introducing simple constraints. Restrictions are added to each variable participating in a constraint, and the additional costs create asymmetry. Proposal 1 There is an asymmetric DCOP that cannot be expressed by a symmetrical DCOP, along with the addition of simple constraints of the form UAi (·) =. Proof: For example, if we look at the interaction shown in Figure 1, UB (·) must be consistent with the costs incurred for each agent, and can be described by the following set of linear equations: UA1 (a, ·) + B (a) and unsymmetrical constraint of each variable UA (·), UB (·) must be consistent with the costs incurred for each agent, and can be described by the following set of linear equations: U1 (a) + B (x), x (b), y (x) (a), x (b).

sections.heading: 2.3.3 Private Events As Variables (PEAV)
sections.text: The PEAV model (Maheswaran et al., 2004b) successfully captures asymmetric payouts within standard DCOPs. The costs of the PEAV model for an agent include a mirror variable for each of its neighbors in the constraint network (i.e. for each limited variable held by another agent).The resulting representation of an asymmetric MAS problem in a PEAV-DCOP is much greater in terms of variables and constraints than an ADCOP. Figure 2 describes the same interaction of Figure 1 with the PEAV (note that this is a minimization problem).

sections.heading: 3. Asymmetric Distributed Complete Search
sections.text: Although DCOPs are very difficult, a large number of previous DCOP research has focused on complete search algorithms (Modi et al., 2005; Yeoh et al., 2010; Petcu & Faltings, 2006; Mailler & Lesser, 2004; Gershman et al., 2009). Unfortunately, most existing complete DCOP algorithms cannot find an optimal solution for solving ADCOPs.

sections.heading: 3.1 Complete Search with Asymmetric Constraints
sections.text: Consider the SyncBB algorithm (Hirayama & Yokoo, 1997). SyncBB was chosen for its simplicity, but this demonstration is relevant to most existing DCOP algorithms, so the total cost of the partial task is minimal. Running a Branch & Bound algorithm implies that the cost of a partial takeover is greater than the cap that the agent who has the partial takeover in front of him assigns his variable, so the total cost of the partial takeover is minimal.

sections.heading: 3.2 ADCOP Complete Search Algorithms
sections.text: Similar to the DCSP case (Brito, Meisels, Meseguer, & Zivan, 2009), both sides of the constraints can usually be executed in two ways: one strategy is to solve the problem in two phases; the first phase is to achieve a complete assignment, taking into account only one side of each constraint - this phase can be executed using a symmetrical DCOP algorithm; the second phase is to verify the full cost of the assignment by verifying the complementary part of all the constraints involved; after the second phase is completed and new limits have been set, the first phase is to continue searching for a better solution until the entire search space is covered; another strategy is to systematically verify both sides of the constraints before achieving an asymmetrical version.

sections.heading: 4. Asymmetric Distributed Local Search
sections.text: Distributed local search algorithms for solving DCOPs have become increasingly popular in recent years. Although local search algorithms are inherently incomplete, i.e. they do not guarantee to report the optimal solution, they provide a practical solution to much larger problems. An additional asymmetry of the problems makes a complete solution process even more difficult, which increases the suitability of the local search for solving ADCOPs. Next, we present an overview of the standard local search algorithms of DCOP, followed by a discussion of their applicability to the asymmetric case.

sections.heading: 4.1 Local Search
sections.text: The general conception of local search algorithms for DCOPs is synchronous. In each step of the algorithm, an agent sends its assignment to all of its neighbors in the limited network and receives the assignments of all of its neighbors. We hereby present in detail two leading algorithms applicable to this general framework - the Distributed Stochastic Algorithm Agents (Zhang et al., 2005) and the Max Gain Message Algorithms (Maheswaran, Pearce, Tambe, 2004a). In the first step of the DSA Algorithm Agents, some value assignments are randomly selected for their variables. Next, agents perform a sequence of steps until each agent sends its value assignment to its neighbors. Each agent sends its value assignment to its neighbors in the Restrictions graph and receives the assignments of its neighbors. The current paper follows the general definition of a DCOP that does not include a synchronization mechanism.

sections.heading: 4.2 Local Search with Asymmetric Constraints
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most of them are in a position to go into a different world, in which they are able to move, in which they move, in which they move, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they, in which they, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they, in which they live.

sections.heading: 4.3 ADCOP Local Search Algorithms
sections.text: The above-mentioned shortcomings of the standard local search algorithms of both the ADCOP model and the PEAV formulation require the development of new local search algorithms specifically designed for ADCOPs. Next, such algorithms are presented that attempt to incorporate information from the agent's local neighborhood and use it to locate high-quality solutions.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Asymmetric Coordinated Local Search (ACLS)
sections.text: The ACLS algorithm presented in Algorithm 6 tries to combine information from the environment of each agent > to generate a global evaluation. It proceeds in synchronous steps and continues (after a random initial assignment) until a condition for termination is met. In each step, an agent begins to execute ACLS by sending its current assignment to its neighbors and collecting assignments from them (line 3-4). It then collects all assignments that can improve its local state (line 5). Based on this improvement, a proposed assignment PV is randomly selected according to the distribution of profits from each proposal (line 6). This proposal is sent to all neighbors and the suggestions of neighbors (line 7,8). An agent receiving an offer responds with the value of its side of the restriction resulting from its current assignment and the proposed assignment is the assignment of LLS (line 7-10).

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Minimal Constraint Sharing MGM (MCS-MGM)
sections.text: Similar to ACLS, the MCS-MGM algorithm depicted in algorithm 7 also tries to use knowledge of the local neighborhood to achieve a better return on the environment. The MCS-MGM algorithm also works in synchronous steps and ends according to a predefined condition. Each step consists of three different interaction phases. An agent starts by exchanging assignments with his neighbors (lines 3-4) and then evaluates the impact of his neighbor's assignment change on his own local state. If the neighbor's assignment change worsens the current state by more than the last known best local reduction of the neighbor, the restriction is passed on to the neighbor, i.e. the agent sends his side of the restriction to his neighbor with the new value of the neighbor and assigns costs from zero to him instead (lines 5-9). The updated restrictions are collected and the local partial problem slightly modified (lines 10-11).

sections.heading: 4.3.3 Guaranteed Convergence Asymmetric MGM (GCA-MGM)
sections.text: Line 7 is replaced by: 7: if ∆ > 0 doWe call the resulting algorithm Guaranteed Convergence Asymmetric MGM (GCAMGM). Guaranteed convergence comes at a price. GCA-MGM is expected to retain less privacy than MCS-MGM because it has a weaker condition for exchanging restrictions between agents (see Section 5). Proposal 5 GCA-MGM is guaranteed to converge to a local optimum in a limited number of steps. Proof evidence: Suppose that GCA-MGM does not converge. As a result, agents repeatedly change their value assignments. Any change that causes an increase for some agents triggers a restriction exchange, and therefore this assignment change will not occur the next time (i.e., cannot converge again).

sections.heading: 5. Experimental Evaluation
sections.text: The experimental evaluation is divided into two parts. In the first part, the performance of the complete ADCOP algorithms presented in Section 3 is compared with the performance of the standard state-of-the-art complete DCOP algorithms when solving asymmetric problems represented by the PEAV formulation. Two standard metrics for the performance of complete algorithms are used - runtime and network load. In the second part of the experimental evaluation they produce, the proposed ADCOP locale search algorithms are compared with the status-of-the-art algorithms to solve DCOPs. The focus of the evaluation of the incomplete algorithms is on the quality of the algorithms they produce in a given limited runtime. As demonstrated by the experimental evaluation, the proposed ADCOP locale search algorithms are converted to a high quality, as opposed to incomplete methods that are not processed.

sections.heading: 5.1 Evaluation of ADCOP Complete Search Algorithms
sections.text: The evaluation of the ADCOP complete search algorithms consists of three experimental settings - two settings of random asymmetric Max DiscSPs, followed by a graphical game setting. 50 random instances were generated for each set of experiments and the results were generated over these 50 instances. In the first group of experiments, random asymmetric Max DiscSPs were generated with 10 agents (n = 10), 10 values (k = 10), density constraints p1 = 0.4, and varying density constraints 0.1 ≤ 0.9. Figures 7 and 8 present the runtime and power charge results of the operation of the proposed ADCOP algorithms. Figure 7 presents the results for the mean number of NCLOs. In these algorithms we measure constraint checks, i.e., NCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCs show that the ATWB runs out for most of the problems.

sections.heading: 5.2 Evaluation of ADCOP Local Search Algorithms
sections.text: The introduced local search algorithms were evaluated over three domains - asymmetric MaxDisCSPs, general form of graphical games and scalable networks. For each type of problem, 500 different problem cases were generated with 200 agents and a domain size of 10 values per agent. The presented results are the average over the 500 solutions obtained by the algorithms for these instances. Asymmetric Max DisCSPs were generated with an average of 10 neighbors per agent (density parameter p2 = 0.7) and tightness parameters are described above for the asymmetric Max DiscSPs generated to evaluate complete algorithms. Generally, graphical game agents had an average of 5 neighbors, i.e., agents were associated with a probability by an asymmetric confrontation.

metadata.abstractText: Distributed Constraint Optimization (DCOP) is a powerful framework for representing and solving distributed combinatorial problems, where the variables of the problem are owned by different agents. Many multi-agent problems include constraints that produce different gains (or costs) for the participating agents. Asymmetric gains of constrained agents cannot be naturally represented by the standard DCOP model. The present paper proposes a general framework for Asymmetric DCOPs (ADCOPs). In ADCOPs different agents may have different valuations for constraints that they are involved in. The new framework bridges the gap between multi-agent problems which tend to have asymmetric structure and the standard symmetric DCOP model. The benefits of the proposed model over previous attempts to generalize the DCOP model are discussed and evaluated. Innovative algorithms that apply to the special properties of the proposed ADCOP model are presented in detail. These include complete algorithms that have a substantial advantage in terms of runtime and network load over existing algorithms (for standard DCOPs) which use alternative representations. Moreover, standard incomplete algorithms (i.e., local search algorithms) are inapplicable to the existing DCOP representations of asymmetric constraints and when they are applied to the new ADCOP framework they often fail to converge to a local optimum and yield poor results. The local search algorithms proposed in the present paper converge to high quality solutions. The experimental evidence that is presented reveals that the proposed local search algorithms for ADCOPs achieve high quality solutions while preserving a high level of privacy.
